facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 877 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 877 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 9, 1963 of Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 410 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 9, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 410 of 1962.

facts.text: Decree passed against the appellant (judgment debtor).

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of a decree passed against the appellant  judg- ment debtor  the judgment creditor

facts.text: Judgment creditor took out execution proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment creditor took out execution proceedings. An auction sale of the factory belonging to the appellant

facts.text: Executing court ordered auction sale of the factory belonging to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: An auction sale of the factory belonging to the appellant was ordered by the executing companyrt.

facts.text: Amin held auction sale on September 10, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that order the Amin  the auction officer  held an auction sale on September 10, 1962.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was the highest bidder for Rs. 2,45,000/-

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 was held to be the highest bidder for Rs. 2,45,000/- .

facts.text: Appellant challenged auction sale alleging Amin did not realise 1/4th of sale proceeds (Rs. 61,250) immediately after auction as required by O.21 R.84.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the auction sale alleging that the Amin had number realised 1/4th of the sale proceeds immediately after the said auction was closed as required by 0.21 R. 84 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Appellant alleged Amin realised the amount and deposited it in Treasury on September 11, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that the Amin realised the said amount and deposited it in the Treasury on ,September 11, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under O.21 R.84 before Civil Judge, Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter filed an application under O. 21 R. 84 before the Civil Judge, Aligarh.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 contested application, stated tendered amount immediately after auction.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 companytested that application stating that he had , tendered the said amount immediately after the auction, that the said amount being large the Amin hesitated

facts.text: Amin hesitated to accept cash due to late hour to deposit in Treasury.

anchor.surface_text: to accept it in cash as it was too late that day to .deposit it in the Treasury.

facts.text: Amin wanted to know if cheque could be accepted, took Chhotelal to Munsif's residence in Hathras.

anchor.surface_text: He also alleged that the Amin wanted ,to know whether he companyld accept a cheque instead of cash and therefore took Chhotelal, his representative, along with him to the residence of the Munsif, Hathras,

facts.text: Amin left Chhotelal in car outside Munsif's residence, consulted Munsif who advised to take cash.

anchor.surface_text: Leaving Chhotelal in the car outside the Munsifs residence, the Amin went in to companysult the Munsif if he companyld accept a cheque but the Munsif advised him to take cash.

facts.text: Amin accepted Rs. 61,250 from Chhotelal in the car and issued receipt there.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Amin returned to the car where he accepted the said amount from Chhotelal and issued there and then a receipt therefor.

facts.text: Civil Judge refused to accept Respondent No.1's case and set aside auction sale as nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The Civil Judge refused to accept the case of respondent No. 1 ,and setting aside the auction sale held it to be a nullity.

facts.text: Civil Judge rejected Amin's report that he accepted money immediately after seeing Munsif outside house.

anchor.surface_text: He rejected the report of the Amin that he had accepted the money immediately after seeing the Munsif outside the Munsifs house where Chhotelal was in the car.

facts.text: Civil Judge found Munsif's evidence did not support Amin as Munsif saw only Amin.

anchor.surface_text: The Civil Judge thought that the Munsifs evidence did number support the Amin as the Munsif had stated that it was only the Amin who had companye to see him.

facts.text: Amin's report dated September 10, 1962 did not mention receiving the amount, receipt issued that day.

anchor.surface_text: What impressed the Civil Judge was the fact that in his report dated September 10, 1962 the Amin had number mentioned the fact of his having received the said amount and the receipt issued by him that day.

facts.text: Endorsement at foot of report made on September 11, 1962 mentioning receipt on Sep 10.

anchor.surface_text: There was however an endorsement at the foot of that report made on September 11, 1962 in which the Amin had mentioned the fact of his having received the said amount

facts.text: Civil Judge held endorsement was afterthought.

anchor.surface_text: the Civil Judge, however, felt that if he had received that amount on September 10, 1962, the Amin was bound to have mentioned that fact in the body of that report

facts.text: Respondent No.1 withdrew Rs.1,51,000 from Bank on that day and had cash available.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the evidence of the Amin, the Munsif and Chhotelal, there was also the evidence that respondent No. 1 had that day withdrawn Rs.1,51,000 from the Bank

facts.text: Respondent No.1 filed appeal against Civil Judge's order in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 filed an appeal against the said order in the High Court.

facts.text: High Court accepted Amin's report and evidence, reversed Civil Judge, held no breach of O.21 R.84, sale not nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the Amins report and his evidence and reversed the judgment and order of the Civil Judge holding that there was numberbreach of 0. 21 R. 84

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to interfere with High Court's finding of fact under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant tried to challenge this finding of fact by the High Court but as the evidence on this question was clear and the High Courts finding was fully justified we,
under Art. 136 declined to permit him to go into the evidence with a view to reopen the said finding.

arguments.claim: S.47 CPC wide, liberally construed to include all execution questions between parties incl. purchaser; avoids separate suit

anchor.surface_text: It has been companysistently held in a number of decisions by the Privy Council and the High Courts that section 47 is wide and should be liberally companystrued so as number to drive the parties to a separate suit and thereby prolong litigation. All questions relating to the execution, discharge or satisfaction of the decree which arise between the parties fall within the scope of this section.

If such an order is a decree it is appealable under section 96 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Order declaring auction sale nullity relates to execution, discharge or satisfaction of decree under S.47

anchor.surface_text: An auction sale is held in pursuance of execution proceedings taken out by the judgment-creditor and the order passed by the executing companyrt. Until the decree is satisfied or discharged the execution proceedings cannot be said to have been companypleted. It is by the payment of sale proceeds resulting from such sale that the decree is satisfied either in part or in whole. That being clearly the position it is difficult to companyprehend as to why as held in Mrs. JPeliti v. Kanshi Gopal 1  an order declaring an auction sale as a nullity cannot be said to be one relating to the execution discharge or satisfaction of the decree within the meaning of section 47.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eposited the balance amount under R. 85 but has failed to lodge a receipt therefor and the companyrt orders re-sale, an application for review of such

holdings.text: Rules 84 and 85 of Order XXI are mandatory; non-compliance results in no sale at all, court bound to order resale; no material irregularity under R.90

anchor.surface_text: In Manilal Mohanlal Shah Ors. v. Sardar Sayed Ahmed Saiyed Mohammed Anr.  1  this Court has held that Rules 84 and 85 of Order XXI being mandatory if they are not complied with there would be no sale at all and the court is bound to order a resale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding Supreme Court precedent in Manilal Mohanlal Shah

holdings.text: An order setting aside auction sale as nullity for non-compliance with O.21 R.84 falls under section 47 CPC

anchor.surface_text: If the order setting aside the sale on the ground that the deposit as provided for under R. 85 was not made falls within the scope of section 47 there does not appear to be any reason why an order holding the sale to be a nullity on the ground that R. 84 was not complied with cannot also fall under that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to orders under R.85; S.47 liberally construed to include all execution questions between parties including purchaser

holdings.text: Determination of question under S.47 CPC is a decree under S.2(2) CPC and appealable under S.96 CPC

anchor.surface_text: Under section 2(2) of the Code a decree is deemed to include the determination of any question falling within section 47. ... Therefore if an order decides a question relating to the rights and liabilities of the parties with reference to the relief granted by the decree it would fall under section 47 and would be a decree within the meaning of section 2(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory definitions of decree and appeal from decree

holdings.text: Order setting aside auction sale as nullity amounts to final decision relating to rights of parties (judgment-debtor and auction purchaser), hence a decree

anchor.surface_text: It is thus manifest that the order setting aside the auction sale amounts to a final decision relating to the rights of the parties in dispute in that particular civil proceeding, such a proceeding being one in which the rights and liabilities of the parties arising from the auction sale are in dispute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows SC precedents on finality (Jethanand, Abdul Rahman); final for purchaser as ends matter between purchaser and JD

holdings.text: Order declaring auction sale nullity relates to execution, discharge or satisfaction of decree under S.47 CPC

anchor.surface_text: An auction sale is held in pursuance of execution proceedings taken out by the judgment-creditor and the order passed by the executing court. Until the decree is satisfied or discharged the execution proceedings cannot be said to have been completed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical connection: sale proceeds satisfy decree; rejects contrary view in Peliti as auction purchaser now party under Explanation to S.47

holdings.text: Order by executing court setting aside auction sale as nullity is appealable

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question whether an order by an executing Court setting aside an auction sale as a nullity is an appealable order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comprehensive: falls under S.47 as final decree determining rights; not interlocutory; R.90 inapplicable; liberally construed S.47

precedents.citation: Manilal Mohanlal Shah Ors. v. Sardar Sayed Ahmed Saiyed Mohammed Anr.  1

anchor.surface_text: Manilal Mohanlal Shah Ors. v. Sardar Sayed Ahmed Saiyed Mohammed Anr.  1  this Court has held that Rules 84 and 85 of Order XXI being mandatory if they are number companylied with there would be numbersale at all and the companyrt is bound to order a resale. That decision also held that since there would be numbersale and the imported sale is nullity there would be numberquestion of a material irregularity in the companyduct of the sale and R. 90 would therefore number apply.

precedents.case_name: Manilal Mohanlal Shah v. Sardar Sayed Ahmed Saiyed Mohammed
precedents.cited_proposition: Rules 84 and 85 of Order XXI are mandatory; non-compliance means no sale in law, court must order resale, R.90 does not apply as no material irregularity but nullity
precedents.cited_holding: if they are number companyplied with there would be numbersale at all and the companyrt is bound to order a resale

anchor.surface_text: Nandlal v. Siddiquan  2 The High Court of Madras has also held that where an auction purchaser has deposited the balance amount under R. 85 but has failed to lodge a receipt therefor and the companyrt orders re-sale, an application for review of such an order falls under section 47 and such an order is appealable.

precedents.cited_proposition: order setting aside auction sale for non-payment of deposit under R.85 falls under section 47 irrespective of whether purchaser is decree-holder or stranger

precedents.citation: Veerayya v. Tirichi- rapalli District Board 3

Various High Courts have similarly held that when a sale in execution of a decree whose validity is number questioned is attacked on the ground that it is number merely irregular but illegal and void that must be done by a proceeding under section 47 and number by an independent suit.

precedents.cited_proposition: where auction purchaser deposited balance under R.85 but failed to lodge receipt, court order for re-sale, review application falls under s.47 and appealable

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Peliti v. Kanshi Gopal 3  where it was held that such an order was number appealable on the ground  1  that an auction purchaser even if he is number a stanger is number a party to the suit and  2  that such an order setting aside an auction sale would number be one relating to the execution, discharge or satisfaction of the decree and therefore number an order under section 47.

precedents.cited_proposition: order setting aside auction sale as nullity not appealable as purchaser not party to suit and not relating to execution/discharge/satisfaction of decree

precedents.citation: Bharat National Bank v. Bhagwan Singh 4

anchor.surface_text: Bharat National Bank v. Bhagwan Singh 4  the judgment-debtor raised three companytentions  1  with regard to his objection to the proclamation of sale,  2  the jurisdiction of the executing companyrt and  3  limitation.

precedents.case_name: Bharat National Bank v. Bhagwan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: order upholding objection to proclamation and ordering fresh sale but rejecting others not final determination as execution not concluded

anchor.surface_text: Md. Zakaria v. Kishun 1  relied on by Counsel for the appellant laid down two propositions  1  that an order under R. 66 of 0.21 was number an appealable order and  2  that the only orders which are appealable are those which determine the rights of the parties to the execution.

precedents.cited_proposition: order under O.21 R.66 not appealable; only orders determining rights of parties to execution are appealable

precedents.citation: Mohit Narain Jha v. Thakan Jha 2

anchor.surface_text: Mohit Narain Jha v. Thakan Jha 2 . is again a case of an order passed under 0.21 R. 66 refusing to numberify a certain lease in the proclamation of sale. There being numberdetermination of the rights of the parties and the order at best being a processual one the High Court was right in holding that such an order was neither a decree number appealable.

precedents.case_name: Mohit Narain Jha v. Thakan Jha
precedents.cited_proposition: order under O.21 R.66 refusing to notify lease in proclamation not determining rights, not appealable

anchor.surface_text: Radhe Lal Ladli Persad 3  which the Counsel referred to does number also assist him but lays down on the companytrary that where a plea which is overruled is the subject of a separate petition under section 4 and it is a self companytained plea with numberreference to the other matters in dispute the order over ruling such a plea is final as regards that particular objection raised by the judgment-debtor and is appealable.

precedents.cited_proposition: order overruling self-contained plea under s.47 without reference to other matters is final and appealable

anchor.surface_text: Pankaj Kumar v. Nanibala 4  the High Court was companycerned with the question whether the order in question was a final order under Art. 133 of the Constitution. The order against which an appeal to this. Court was sought for was one dismissing certain objections raised by the judgment-debtor.

precedents.cited_proposition: order dismissing judgment-debtor's objections not final under Art.133 as does not dispose of execution proceedings

precedents.citation: Mrs. J. Peliti v. Kanshi Gopal 5

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. J. Peliti v. Kanshi Gopal 5  numbere of the decisions relied on by Counsel relates to the question before us and therefore they are number of any assistance.

precedents.case_name: Mrs. J. Peliti v. Kanshi Gopal

precedents.citation: Jethanand Sons v. State of Uttar Pradesh 6

anchor.surface_text: Jethanand Sons v. State of Uttar Pradesh 6  in the following terms An order is final if it amounts to a final decision relating to the rights of the parties in dispute in the civil proceeding.

precedents.case_name: Jethanand and Sons v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: final order is one that amounts to final decision on rights in dispute; if proceeding still to be tried, not final
precedents.cited_holding: An order is final if it amounts to a final decision relating to the rights of the parties in dispute in the civil proceeding. If after the order the civil proceeding still remains to be tried and the rights in dispute between the parties had to be determined, the order is number a final order

precedents.citation: Abdul Rahman v. D. K. Cassim 1

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Rahman v. D. K. Cassim 1  Sir George Lowndes observed The finality must be finality in relation to the suit. If after the order the suit is still alive in which rights of the parties have still to be determined numberappeal lies against it.

precedents.case_name: Abdul Rahman v. D. K. Cassim
precedents.cited_proposition: finality must relate to the suit; if suit still alive, no appeal even if decides vital issue
precedents.cited_holding: The finality must be finality in relation to the suit. If after the order the suit is still alive in which rights of the parties have still to be determined numberappeal lies against it. The fact that the order decides an important and even a vital issue is by itself number material.

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. JPeliti v. Kanshi Gopal 1  an order declaring an auction sale as a nullity cannot be said to be one relating to the execution discharge or satisfaction of the decree within the meaning of section 47.

precedents.cited_proposition: order declaring auction sale nullity not relating to execution etc.

anchor.surface_text: In Manilal Mohanlal Shah Ors. v. Sardar Sayed Ahmed Saiyed Mohammed Anr.  1  this Court has held that Rules 84 and 85 of Order XXI being mandatory if they are not complied with there would be no sale at all and the court is bound to order a resale.

Counsel for the appellant tried to challenge this finding of fact by the High Court but as the evidence on this question was clear and the High Courts finding was fully justified we, in our discretion under Art. 136 declined to permit him to go into the evidence with a view to reopen the said finding.

anchor.surface_text: If the order setting aside the sale on the ground that the deposit as provided for under R. 85 was not made falls within the scope of section 47 there does not appear to be any reason why an order holding the sale to be a nullity on the ground that R. 84 was not complied with cannot also fall under that section.

Counsel for the appellant tried to challenge this finding of fact by the High Court but as the evidence on this question was clear and the High Courts finding was fully justified we, in our discretion under Art. 136 declined to permit him to go into the evidence with a view to reopen the said finding.

edges.explanation: Holding that determination under S.47 is a decree under S.2(2) addresses whether such order amounts to a decree

anchor.surface_text: Under section 2(2) of the Code a decree is deemed to include the determination of any question falling within section 47. ... Therefore if an order decides a question relating to the rights and liabilities of the parties with reference to the relief granted by the decree it would fall under section 47 and would be a decree within the meaning of section 2(2).

Counsel for the appellant tried to challenge this finding of fact by the High Court but as the evidence on this question was clear and the High Courts finding was fully justified we, in our discretion under Art. 136 declined to permit him to go into the evidence with a view to reopen the said finding.

It is thus manifest that the order setting aside the auction sale amounts to a final decision relating to the rights of the parties in dispute in that particular civil proceeding, such a proceeding being one in which the rights and liabilities of the parties arising from the auction sale are in dispute

Counsel for the appellant tried to challenge this finding of fact by the High Court but as the evidence on this question was clear and the High Courts finding was fully justified we, in our discretion under Art. 136 declined to permit him to go into the evidence with a view to reopen the said finding.

anchor.surface_text: An auction sale is held in pursuance of execution proceedings taken out by the judgment-creditor and the order passed by the executing court. Until the decree is satisfied or discharged the execution proceedings cannot be said to have been completed.

Counsel for the appellant tried to challenge this finding of fact by the High Court but as the evidence on this question was clear and the High Courts finding was fully justified we, in our discretion under Art. 136 declined to permit him to go into the evidence with a view to reopen the said finding.
